Preterm babies (preemies) may not get enough oxygen (hypoxia) which can cause retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), motor and cognitive disabilities, brain injuries, hearing loss, blindness, cerebral palsy (CP) and death. They may need extra oxygen to reach normal levels of oxygen in their blood.[^176][^177][^178][^179][^180][^175][^181]

Supplemental oxygen helps prevent hypoxia, but too much oxygen (hyperoxia) can cause retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), cancer, lung disease, developmental disabilities, infection, inflammation, fibrosis, and other health conditions.[^176][^177][^178][^179][^180][^175][^181]

Preterm babies have less antioxidants and immature lungs which can increase the harmful effects of oxygen.[^176][^177][^178][^179][^180][^175][^181]

![Preemie pulse oximeter](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/5iizL3bwVOOMwSsqkgMyeu/b0f40853f5b45443e7864b5cbaf2551c/Preemie_pulse_oximeter.jpg)

![Pulse Oximeter](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/62HmzU3IeA4QugCgOKEKKw/267477dfe9966f5d1053a8ae68e08060/Pulse_Oximeter.jpg)

Pulse oximeter alarms need to be on when a preterm baby is receiving supplemental oxygen. Manually monitoring a preterm baby on supplemental oxygen is not as accurate as a pulse oximeter with alarms.[^182][^183]

When the SpO2 level goes below 95% giving too much oxygen at once should be avoided, which will bring the baby’s SpO2 over 95%.[^182]

Prevention of hypoxia & hyperoxia[^177][^178][^179][^180][^182][^183][^184][^185][^181]:

- Accurate oxygen level assessment by continuous pulse oximetry with alarms
- Continuous oxygen monitoring to maintain SpO2 range above 91% and below 95%
- Supplemental oxygen given when the preterm baby is on continuous pulse oximetry with alarms
- Decreasing unnecessary supplemental oxygen unless needed

 __Use the Hospital Plan of Care form to advocate and ask questions about your loved one.__
